metadata.title: AWS Security Agent Functional Testing Report
metadata.author: Security Analysis

abstract: The AWS Security Agent is an AI‑powered service that integrates design review, code review and on‑demand penetration testing into the software development lifecycle. It evaluates an application's design documents, source code and live deployments against organizational security requirements and common vulnerabilities. This report analyzes the functionality of AWS Security Agent based on expert testing and publicly available information. It maps the observations back to officially documented features where possible, identifies limitations and gaps, and assesses the extent to which the tool addresses the OWASP Top 10 web‑application risks. The study found that AWS Security Agent offers context‑aware multi‑step penetration testing, real‑time pull‑request analysis, and automated design reviews, but it currently operates only through a web console in the US East (N. Virginia) preview and has important limitations. It partially covers several OWASP Top 10 categories but does not provide full coverage without additional controls. Note: A Medium Q&A article was initially reviewed but was found to contain unverified claims and appears to be AI-generated content spreading potentially false information. All information from that source has been removed from this report, as modern information sources require precise verification against official documentation.

sections.title: Introduction
paragraphs: Application security teams must secure applications as they evolve through design, coding and deployment. Traditional security reviews and penetration tests are typically manual and scheduled infrequently, leading to gaps and late findings. AWS introduced the "Security Agent" as a frontier AI agent designed to embed security into each stage of the software development lifecycle [7]. The agent provides design reviews, code security reviews and multi‑step penetration testing within a centralized web interface, aiming to make expert‑level security assessments available on demand and at scale [7]. The official documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent operates across AWS, on-premise, hybrid, multicloud, and SaaS environments [7] and consolidates findings from design, code and penetration tests in one place.

subsections.title: Design Security Review
paragraphs: The design review capability allows security teams to upload design documents (architectural diagrams, system designs, data‑flow diagrams and threat models) and assess them against organizational security requirements. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent shifts security left by providing real-time security feedback on design documents and assessing compliance with organizational security requirements before any code is written [7]. Security teams upload documents through the web application and receive remediation guidance to prioritize findings [7]. The agent supports custom security requirements-teams can define description, applicability, compliance criteria and remediation guidance for each requirement. The expert noted that custom requirements are defined through free‑text fields limited to 500 characters for descriptions and 10 000 characters for other fields, and the underlying model interprets them, which may change over time. The design review runs entirely in the external web application opened from the AWS console. Supported formats include markdown, PDF and common architectural diagram formats, but uploading is done manually; there is currently no CLI or API to automate submissions.

subsections.title: Code Security Review
paragraphs: Code review analyzes pull requests in source control repositories against security requirements and the OWASP Top 10. The official AWS documentation states that AWS Security Agent proactively secures applications by analyzing pull requests against organizational security requirements and common vulnerabilities like missing input validation and SQL injection risks [7]. Developers receive remediation guidance directly in their GitHub workflow [7]. The official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub confirms that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and that draft pull requests are not analyzed [15]. The AWS News Feed article notes that the agent's code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [5]. The official AWS documentation only mentions GitHub integration [15]. The expert observed that the public preview integrates only with GitHub via a GitHub App, supports up to 20 private repositories per integration [14] and does not scan public repositories. Pull requests are the only unit of analysis—full repository scans are not supported. Remediation guidance and suggested fixes are posted directly in the developer's workflow, but customizing the checks beyond the defined security requirements is limited.

subsections.title: On‑Demand Penetration Testing
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent's penetration testing capability performs multi‑step attack simulations on web applications. The official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent delivers on-demand penetration testing by deploying specialized AI agents to discover, validate, report and remediate security vulnerabilities through tailored multi-step attack scenarios [7]. The agent understands the application's context by analyzing source code and documentation to identify and exploit vulnerabilities that automated security scanning tools cannot find [7]. It documents findings with impact analysis, reproducible attack paths, and creates pull requests with ready-to-implement code fixes [7]. The official AWS documentation for creating penetration tests specifies that only verified domains can be included in penetration tests and that VPC configuration is only required for testing private applications hosted within an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud [16]. It is promoted as automating context‑aware penetration tests that scale across many applications [2]. The National CIO Review notes that the agent continuously scans workloads for vulnerabilities and performs penetration testing tailored to the application's structure and intended behavior, eliminating the need to wait for human‑led assessments [8]. The ComputerWeekly report adds that the agent understands the design, code and security requirements of a workload and can create a customised attack plan to expose vulnerabilities before an application reaches production [9]. During testing, the expert noted that all penetration tests require a verified domain (with DNS TXT record) [16], and for private applications hosted within a VPC, additional VPC configuration is also required [16]. Tests can include contextual artifacts such as API documentation, threat models, source code archives and GitHub repositories. Only HTTP/HTTPS targets are supported; custom ports and other protocols are not. The agent creates multiple action groups (information disclosure, business logic vulnerabilities, unrestricted resource consumption, authentication bypass, etc.), uses static analysis tasks to inspect the source, and then launches validators that exploit vulnerabilities to minimise false positives. The risk categories available for testing include arbitrary file upload, code injection, command injection, cross‑site scripting (XSS), insecure direct object references, JSON Web Token vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, server‑side request forgery (SSRF), server‑side template injection, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks.

subsections.title: Setup and Permissions
paragraphs: The expert tested AWS Security Agent using a read‑only IAM user and gradually added permissions. The web console provided clear error messages for many missing permissions, but some errors required examining logs to identify the missing IAM policies. Managing IAM permissions required trial‑and‑error because the documentation did not list all the required permissions, which complicates automation. The agent can only be enabled via the AWS console; there is no CLI, CloudFormation template or SDK interface for configuration-making it a click‑ops process. All interactions occur via a web console with no CLI or official AWS CLI commands available. The preview is available only in the us‑east‑1 region and requires creation of an "Agent Space". Connecting GitHub triggers installation of a GitHub App with repository access restricted to selected private repositories. The expert observed a limit of 20 repositories and noted that public repositories and other SCM systems were not supported, contradicting marketing claims of multi‑SCM support.

subsections.title: Design Review Findings
paragraphs: The design review accepts supported file types via manual upload. In some highly regulated environments, uploading documents through a web UI may be blocked, limiting adoption. The expert tested the service with basic design documents and observed that policies such as "Secure by Default, Tenant Isolation, Secret Protection, Trusted Cryptography, Audit Logging, Authorization, Log Protection, Information Protection, Privileged Access and Authentication" were applied. When the design intentionally violated requirements, the agent failed corresponding policies; when the design mentioned the required topics, half of the policies were marked as needing more details. Uploading irrelevant documents led to all policies being marked not applicable. Custom security requirements worked as expected; a test rule that forbade Star Wars or Harry Potter terms triggered when those terms appeared in variable names. However, the manual upload process and lack of automation make it difficult to integrate design review into CI/CD pipelines.

subsections.title: Code Review Findings
paragraphs: Code review worked only for private GitHub repositories configured through the GitHub App. Pull requests were evaluated against the same security requirements used for design review and against common vulnerability patterns. The agent does not analyze entire codebases-only changes in pull requests. The expert could reuse custom security requirements across design and code reviews. There is no support for public repositories, and integration with other source control systems (Bitbucket, GitLab, CodeCommit) was not present in the preview. Only up to 20 repositories can be connected. The expert noted that the underlying language model performing analysis is not documented; thus the behaviour may change as models are updated. This lack of determinism makes it difficult to rely on the tool for strict policy enforcement. The tool offers two modes: one to check custom security requirements and another to detect "security vulnerability findings" that resemble the output of Amazon CodeGuru Reviewer; the latter uses rules similar to open‑source tools like Bandit and Infer.

subsections.title: Penetration Testing Findings
paragraphs: To start a penetration test, users must verify ownership of a target domain by creating a DNS TXT record. Automatic verification via Route53 often fails, requiring manual DNS record creation. The penetration testing workflow opens in an external web application separate from the main AWS console. Tests can target an external domain or run from within a VPC; however, the tool does not support VPCs using the 10.0.0.0/16 CIDR because it conflicts with the agent's addressing. Custom ports and non‑HTTP protocols are unsupported; specifying a port in the URL causes the run to start but never succeeds. When a VPC is selected, outbound internet connectivity is required even to fetch GitHub context. Penetration tests also request CloudWatch log groups as destinations, but pre‑created log groups sometimes fail validation due to undocumented naming conventions; leaving the field blank allows the agent to create log groups automatically. Contextual resources can include S3 buckets (only plaintext API documentation, threat models or zipped source code archives), GitHub repositories and plain‑text credentials via the UI. Lambda functions and Secrets Manager entries are used solely to provide authentication credentials. During scanning, the agent builds a sitemap, performs static analysis of frameworks, business logic, important flows and misconfigurations, and then launches validator tasks for risk categories such as arbitrary file upload, code and command injection, XSS, IDOR, JWT vulnerabilities, local file inclusion, path traversal, privilege escalation, SSRF, SSTI, SQL injection and XML external entity attacks. The agent uses tools like testssl.sh to check TLS configurations. It produces detailed findings with CVSS scores, exploit steps and remediation guidance. However, exploitation of complex vulnerabilities that require running external tooling or interacting with local services (labelled "Hard" by the tester) is not supported. Custom exploitation code added to the context caused hallucinations—e.g., the agent incorrectly marked a vulnerability as CVE‑2021‑21311 based on proof for CVE‑2018‑7667. Additionally, the service prohibits creation of custom infrastructure or use of localhost services, limiting validation of sophisticated scenarios.

sections.title: Limitations and Gaps
paragraphs: The following tables summarise limitations identified during testing and map them to available documentation where possible. Table 1 lists limitations mentioned in official AWS sources (blogs, builder posts or Q&A) and confirmed through testing. Table 2 lists limitations observed during testing that are not mentioned in the sources reviewed.

tables.caption: Table 1 – Documented limitations corroborated by testing
rows: Service is in preview and available only in US East (N. Virginia)
AWS News Feed notes that AWS Security Agent is free during the preview and available only in the US East (N. Virginia) region [5].
The expert was only able to create an agent space in us‑east‑1; other regions were not available.
Access is through a web‑based interface with no CLI
The service provides a centralized web‑based interface for managing design, code and penetration tests.
Configuration, design uploads, repository integration and test execution can only be performed via the console and external web app; there is no AWS CLI or SDK support.
Design review requires manual upload of documents
Design review analyzes architectural documents uploaded through a centralized web interface.
Design files must be uploaded via the UI; there is no API to automate document submission, making CI/CD integration difficult.
Code review analyzes GitHub pull requests rather than full repositories
AWS News Feed states that code review checks GitHub pull requests for OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities and policy violations [5].
The preview only reviews pull requests on private repositories; it does not scan entire codebases.
Multi‑step penetration testing simulates realistic attacks
Official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent delivers on-demand penetration testing by deploying specialized AI agents through tailored multi-step attack scenarios [7].
The penetration testing feature created validators that exploited vulnerabilities and provided exploit paths, reducing false positives.
Integrates organisational security requirements

Official AWS documentation states that security teams define organizational security requirements once in the AWS Console, and AWS Security Agent automatically enforces these requirements throughout development [7].
Custom policies were applied consistently in design and code review; tests with Star Wars and Harry Potter terms triggered the custom rule.
On-demand accessibility for security reviews

Official AWS documentation confirms that AWS Security Agent provides immediate access to security expertise, enabling teams to run design reviews, code analyses, and penetration tests on-demand whenever needed [7].
The expert was able to trigger design reviews, code reviews, and penetration tests immediately through the web interface without scheduling delays.
Actionable fixes with pull requests for confirmed vulnerabilities

Official AWS documentation states that AWS Security Agent validates security findings through proof-based exploitation and creates pull requests with ready-to-implement fixes in developer-friendly language [7].
The expert observed that penetration test findings included detailed exploit paths and remediation guidance, though the pull request creation feature was not tested in the preview.
Only GitHub integration available for code review

Official AWS documentation for reviewing code security findings in GitHub states that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" in repositories where code review capability is enabled, and only GitHub is mentioned throughout the documentation [15]. The documentation does not mention support for other source control systems.
The preview only supports GitHub integration; other SCM systems (GitLab, Bitbucket, CodeCommit) are not available, contradicting marketing claims of multi-SCM support.
Draft pull requests are not analyzed
Official AWS documentation explicitly states that draft pull requests are not analyzed by AWS Security Agent [15].
Code review only triggers when pull requests are marked as "Ready for review"; draft pull requests are ignored.
Limit of 20 integrated resources per integration
Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrated resources per integration are limited to 20 per integration, and this quota is not adjustable [14].
Large organizations may have more repositories than allowed and must manage multiple integrations or agent spaces.
Limit of 20 integrations per account per region
Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that integrations are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [14].
Organizations with many repositories may need to create multiple agent spaces or request quota increases.
Limit of 20 custom security requirements per account per region
Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that custom security requirements are limited to 20 per account per region, and this quota is not adjustable [14].
Organizations with extensive security policies may need to prioritize which requirements to configure.
Concurrent pentest runs limited to 5 per account per region
Official AWS documentation on Service Quotas specifies that concurrent pentest runs are limited to 5 per account per region, though this quota is adjustable [14].
Multiple penetration tests can run simultaneously, but the limit may require scheduling for organizations with high testing needs.
Only verified domains can be included in penetration tests

Official AWS documentation for creating penetration tests explicitly states that only verified domains can be included in penetration tests and that the URL must match a domain previously verified in AWS Security Agent [16].
Domain verification is a prerequisite for penetration testing, adding setup overhead.
VPC configuration required only for private applications

Official AWS documentation for creating penetration tests states that VPC configuration is only required for testing private applications hosted within an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud, and that this step should be skipped if target domains are publicly accessible [16].
Private applications require additional VPC, subnet, and security group configuration, while public applications do not.

tables.caption: Table 2 – Limitations observed in the preview not documented in sources
rows: No documented list of required IAM permissions; error messages sometimes ambiguous
Administrators must experiment with permissions; deployment scripts or automation cannot easily determine the minimal set.
Public repositories unsupported

Official AWS documentation only mentions GitHub integration and does not specify whether public repositories are supported [15]. The expert observed that only private repositories can be scanned, preventing open-source projects from using the service.
Lack of scheduling or API for running tests
Tests must be triggered manually via the console; cannot integrate penetration tests into CI/CD pipelines or scheduled assessments.
Design review and code review rely on manual uploads and cannot fetch from VPC or internal file shares
Organizations with strict egress controls or blocked uploads cannot use the feature; files must be manually uploaded to an external web app.
Domain verification often fails via Route53; manual DNS TXT record creation required
Adds friction to setup and requires DNS access; automatic verification appears unreliable.
VPC restrictions: 10.0.0.0/16 cannot be used; VPC must have outbound internet connectivity
Common corporate VPC ranges conflict with the agent; penetration tests inside a VPC fail if there is no outbound connectivity.
Only HTTP/HTTPS targets supported; custom ports unsupported
Applications listening on non‑standard ports or protocols cannot be tested; specifying a port in the URL causes the test to hang or fail without clear error messages.
CloudWatch log group naming conventions undocumented; pre‑created log groups rejected
Users must allow the agent to create log groups automatically; otherwise configuration errors occur.
Risk of hallucinated vulnerabilities when additional exploit code is provided
The agent may misattribute vulnerabilities (e.g., marking CVE‑2021‑21311 validated using proof for CVE‑2018‑7667), reducing confidence in findings.
Complex exploitation scenarios requiring custom tooling or local services unsupported
"Hard" vulnerability exploitation cannot be validated; local or external attack tools cannot be executed within the agent's environment.
Underlying language model and its updates are not exposed
Behaviour may change over time; results may not be reproducible and cannot be tuned for determinism.

paragraphsAfter: Table 2 summarises limitations observed in the preview that are not mentioned in the documentation reviewed.

sections.title: OWASP Top 10 Coverage Evaluation
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent claims to detect OWASP Top Ten vulnerabilities in its code review and penetration testing features [5]. The OWASP Top 10:2025 lists the most critical web‑application security risks, including Broken Access Control (A01), Security Misconfiguration (A02), Software Supply Chain Failures (A03), Cryptographic Failures (A04), Injection (A05), Insecure Design (A06), Authentication Failures (A07), Software or Data Integrity Failures (A08), Security Logging and Alerting Failures (A09) and Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions (A10) [12]. Table 3 evaluates coverage of these categories based on the documented and observed capabilities of AWS Security Agent. Where coverage is partial or absent, additional controls are recommended.

table.caption: Table 3 – OWASP Top 10 (2025) coverage by AWS Security Agent
rows: A01: Broken Access Control
Unauthorized access, privilege escalation, IDOR
Partial

Penetration testing checks for insecure direct object references and privilege escalation. Design and code review can enforce authorization and privileged access requirements, but the tool does not perform comprehensive access‑control testing on running services or APIs.
A02: Security Misconfiguration
Default configurations, missing patches, misconfigured permissions
Partial

Static analysis and penetration tests include "security misconfiguration" action groups that analyse frameworks and TLS configurations using tools like testssl.sh. However, the service does not assess infrastructure as code or cloud configuration and cannot patch misconfigurations.
A03: Software Supply Chain Failures
Dependency confusion, compromised packages
Not covered
AWS Security Agent does not inspect third‑party dependencies or SBOMs. It focuses on design documents, pull requests and runtime behaviour rather than supply‑chain risks.
A04: Cryptographic Failures
Weak or missing encryption, insecure random number generation
Limited

Organizational requirements can include "Trusted Cryptography" policies, but the agent does not automatically analyse cryptographic primitives or detect insecure algorithms beyond TLS configuration checks.
A05: Injection
SQL injection, command injection, code injection, XSS
Covered

Penetration tests explicitly target SQL injection, code injection, command injection, server‑side template injection and XML external entity attacks. Code review checks for OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities including injection flaws [5].
A06: Insecure Design
Lack of secure design patterns, threat modeling gaps
Partial

Design review assesses architectural documents against security requirements and can enforce secure‑by‑default patterns. However, complex insecure designs may not be detected if requirements are incomplete or if the upload process is skipped.
A07: Authentication Failures
Weak authentication, credential stuffing, brute force
Partial

Penetration tests include "authentication bypass" validators in static analysis but do not perform password spraying or account lockout tests. Design and code review can enforce authentication and secret‑protection policies.
A08: Software or Data Integrity Failures
Deserialization flaws, untrusted data propagation
Limited

The agent's penetration tests may detect local file inclusion or path traversal but do not analyse deserialization or update mechanisms. Integrity protection is partly covered by organizational policies.
A09: Security Logging and Alerting Failures
Missing logs, ineffective monitoring
Not covered

Although the agent can send logs to CloudWatch, it does not assess whether an application generates sufficient security logs or whether alerting is configured. Log protection is a design‑review policy rather than an active test.
A10: Mishandling of Exceptional Conditions
Improper error handling, denial of service
Not covered
The service does not test for resource exhaustion, race conditions or improper error handling; it focuses on injection and access issues.

paragraphsAfter: Overall, AWS Security Agent provides good coverage for injection‑related vulnerabilities (A05) and some aspects of access control and security misconfiguration. It partially addresses insecure design and authentication issues through design and code review policies. However, the service does not currently address software supply chain failures, cryptographic failures beyond TLS checks, logging and alerting issues or mishandling of exceptional conditions. Organizations relying on AWS Security Agent should augment it with additional tools and processes (e.g., dependency scanning, secrets management, infrastructure‑as‑code security, and runtime monitoring) to achieve comprehensive OWASP Top 10 coverage.

sections.title: Conclusion and Recommendations
paragraphs: AWS Security Agent represents a shift toward continuous, embedded application security. It automates design and code reviews, runs realistic multi‑step penetration tests and centralizes findings, enabling teams to identify issues earlier and reduce manual effort. The service's context‑aware approach, custom security requirements and multi‑step attack simulations are valuable features. However, the preview version has notable limitations: it is available only in one region, requires manual configuration through a web interface, supports only private GitHub repositories, lacks scheduling and API automation, and cannot handle complex exploitation scenarios or non‑HTTP protocols. Some marketing claims (multi‑SCM support and scheduled testing) are not yet realized. Additionally, the tool covers injection vulnerabilities well but provides limited or no coverage for several OWASP Top 10 categories such as supply chain, cryptographic and logging failures. To fully secure their applications, organizations should use AWS Security Agent as a complementary control alongside other security tools (SCA, SAST/DAST scanners, infrastructure security checks) and maintain human expertise for nuanced assessments.

references.title: New AWS Security Agent secures applications proactively from design to deployment (preview)
references.description: Official AWS News Blog post announcing AWS Security Agent in preview, describing capabilities including design review, code review, multi‑step penetration testing, realistic attack simulations, prioritized remediation guidance, and context-aware security testing

references.title: New AWS Security Agent secures applications proactively from design to deployment (preview)
references.description: AWS News Feed post summarising features including automated design, code and penetration tests, context awareness and OWASP Top 10 code checks

references.title: AWS Debuts Security Agent for Automated Code-Level Protection
references.description: National CIO Review article noting that AWS Security Agent automates penetration testing tailored to application design and code

references.title: AWS targets vulnerable code with security agent
references.description: ComputerWeekly report highlighting that AWS Security Agent continuously scans for security violations, conducts on‑demand penetration tests and ties security across the development lifecycle

references.title: OWASP Top 10:2025
references.description: OWASP Top 10:2025 list of application security risks

references.title: What is AWS Security Agent? - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing key capabilities (design security review, code security review, penetration testing), benefits (on-demand accessibility, automatic validation of organizational requirements, scalable security expertise, actionable fixes, multi and hybrid cloud support), and how the service operates across the development lifecycle

references.title: Service Quotas - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation listing service quotas including operations quotas (pentest hours: 80/month, design reviews: 200/month, code reviews: 1,000/month) and configuration quotas (integrations: 20 per account per region, integrated resources per integration: 20, custom security requirements: 20 per account per region, concurrent pentest runs: 5 per account per region)

references.title: Review code security findings in GitHub - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation explaining how code review works in GitHub, including that code review is triggered when a pull request is marked as "Ready for review" and that draft pull requests are not analyzed

references.title: Create a penetration test - AWS Security Agent
references.description: Official AWS Security Agent documentation describing how to create penetration tests, including prerequisites, configuration of test scope, target domains (only verified domains can be tested), VPC resources (only required for private applications), authentication credentials, and additional resources
